centralQuestion: Are the arts worth receiving significant federal funding?

reasons.description: Public investment in the arts generates economic spillovers and supports jobs across creative sectors and local economies.

sources.title: OECD: 'The economic and social impact of the cultural and creative sectors'
Associated Press: 'NEA funding fight is also a fight about jobs'

reasons.description: Arts education and participation improve academic, social, and civic outcomes, providing a public-good rationale for federal support.

sources.title: Brookings Institution: 'New evidence of the benefits of arts education'
RAND Corporation: 'Gifts of the Muse: Reframing the Debate About the Benefits of the Arts'

reasons.description: Federal grants bolster equity and access—especially for small, rural, and underserved communities—and stabilize nonprofit arts organizations.

sources.title: Urban Institute: 'What is the financial risk to nonprofits of losing government grants?'
PBS NewsHour: 'Local arts groups face budget gaps and layoffs as NEA pulls grants'

reasons.description: Cultural funding advances soft power, civic cohesion, and democratic vitality—benefits not easily provided by private markets alone.

sources.title: UNESCO: 'Culture: the missing pillar of sustainable development'

objections.description: Government subsidies can distort markets, reduce efficiency, and encourage dependence rather than innovation in cultural organizations.

sources.title: Fraser Institute: 'Entertainment industries, government policies, and the subsidy system'
The Economist: 'The show must go on'

objections.description: Federal arts funding is vulnerable to politicization and censorship pressures, making support unpredictable and potentially compromising artistic independence.

sources.title: Reuters: 'Judge allows Trump’s executive order restricting many federal arts grants'
The Guardian: 'Arts agency terminates dozens of grants after Trump proposes eliminating NEA'

objections.description: Public arts subsidies can skew toward elite institutions and crowd out private giving; private patronage and platforms can fund culture without federal support.

sources.title: BBC News: 'Who should fund the arts?'
The Economist: 'Patreon, Kickstarter and the new patrons of the arts'

objections.description: Given fiscal constraints, federal arts support is a lower priority relative to other national needs, and proposed cuts are framed as budget discipline.

sources.title: Reuters: 'US House passes Trump cuts of $9.4 billion for foreign aid and public broadcasting'
NPR: 'What arts funding might look like during Trump’s second term'

research.title: ‘Neutrality, Cultural Literacy, and Arts Funding’ (Ergo, 2024)
research.description: Peer-reviewed, open-access philosophical analysis arguing that diversity-based arts funding produces non-excludable public goods by fostering cultural literacy that benefits citizens broadly.

research.title: ‘The impact of out-of-school visual art activities on children’s academic attainment’ (PLOS ONE, 2024)
research.description: Open-access empirical study (N=1,624) finding associations between participation in visual art activities and improved academic attainment, relevant to claims that arts engagement yields educational benefits.

research.title: ‘Cultural policy beyond economy: democratising access to the arts’ (International Journal of Cultural Policy, 2025)
research.description: Open-access article examining how public cultural policy can expand equitable access to the arts, situating funding choices within broader participation and inclusion goals.

research.title: ‘The Impact of Cultural Capital on Economic Growth’ (Sustainability, 2024)
research.description: Open-access paper modeling the contribution of cultural capital and public investment in cultural assets to economic growth, offering macro-level support for culture’s economic externalities.
